header.title: How Sexism Affects us all | Julia Hardy | TEDxYYC
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Julia Hardy tells us how she uses humour to combat endemic online sexism, and explains how the actions of this small percentage of men not only adversely affect and change women's behaviour, but actually cause detriment to other men.  Julie Hardy is a technology and gaming expert based in London, UK and hosts a new radio show on video game culture on BBC Radio 1. Specializing in technology, video games, YouTube and pretty much anything to do with the online self, Julia's work has been featured by BBC TV, Bravo and BAFTA. Julia takes a passionate stance on online issues and created a blog called Misogyny Monday as a platform to raise awareness of the abuse that many women encounter online. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

itsjuliahardy, you don't have to check the meaning behind words every time somebody voices their opinion. This happens at varying degrees, but the human brain can develop an understanding of meaning behind what is said given the context of the situation in which the thing is being said.
On "I'd like to fuck you in the ass whilst grabbing your tits."
That phrase does have several meanings given a certain context. Obviously, in the context of your sentence, the phrase means: a set of words used to describe a behavior I believe to be certainly defined and applicable in only a particular way.
In the context of my sentence, the phrase means: a set of words used as a quote in order to show that the meaning of the phrase has variance.
The meaning is clear in the context of an attractive person walking by, and someone said," I'd like to fuck you in the ass whilst grabbing your tits."
In the context of poetry "I'd like to fuck you in the ass whilst grabbing your tits." has an array of meaning. Perhaps the poet is trying to portray a sense of strong, animalistic-type love for their partner. Perhaps the poet is trying to portray aggressive lust. Perhaps the poet is trying to portray a sense of sting to a lover they'd like to show disdain to. Perhaps the poet is trying to portray a sense of hedonism and the unfulfilling life therein. Perhaps the poet is trying to portray a sense of incapability to break the bonds of biological programming. Perhaps...perhaps...perhaps...
(So I suppose I just argued how "I'd like to fuck you in the ass whilst grabbing your tits." does have multiple meanings)
This is why people like Menace exist, those that disagree with PC-policing.
For more tangible examples that was used by the speaker (you):
"So shes a games journalist... she must give real good head to her editor"
Presumably, the context invokes the meaning that the person disagrees with the ethical integrity of the person under criticism with regards to their journalistic career.
"British slut"
The meaning of the statement can be derived from the context of the situation. Perhaps the person under criticism was cheating on their partner with a string of lovers, playing each person like a fiddle, destroying the lives and relationships of a fair amount of people, all so that the person could get a top position at the corporation they worked at. Or perhaps the person under scrutiny fucked her partners sister, father, mother, and son; lied about it, then proceeded to shame the person cheated on for kissing some girl when they got a bit too drunk the night before. 

So yes, the PC solution is not a good one to support. Why?
Because you prevent a poet from expressing their thoughts about their life and publishing it; you prevent the truly disgraceful (relative to your definition of disgraceful) from behaving in such a way that warrants mockery; you prevent sarcasm from boiling the misjudgment of idiocy;  you prevent disdain to those that are distasteful; you prevent etc...
For people that say stuff that you find stupid, then your best solution is to not care and tell them to fuck off (or some variant of this sort). But more often than not, people's intentions are more than naught; therefore, consider the possibilities and don't be so sensitive.
